sen.j: 牓示（ぼうじ）とは、所領などの土地の四至あるいは境界のうち重要な地点に立てた掲示のこと。
sen.e: The term "Boji" means a notice which was put up at shishi (northern, southern, eastern and western boundary) of the territory or the important positions of boundary.

sen.j: 寺社の境内の境界や一円支配が確立した荘園の排他的権利の及ぶ範囲を示す境界線として立てられた。
sen.e: It was put up in order to show a boundary of the precincts of temples/shrines or that of the land where shoen (manor), which accomplished ichienshihai (complete rule over the land), could exert its exclusive right.

sen.j: 牓示は自然物（岩や立木など）がその役目を果たすこともあったが、通常は木や石で作られた柱が用いられた。
sen.e: Under normal circumstances, poles made of wood or stone were put up as boji though natural objects (rocks or trees) sometimes played a role of boji.

sen.j: 荘園の認定時に荘園領主の使者や荘官、朝廷の使者、国衙の役人が立ちあって立てられた。
sen.e: When shoen was acknowledged, boji was put up in the presence of the envoy of the lord of shoen, the envoy of the Imperial Court and the official of kokuga (provincial government).

sen.j: 牓示は境界を明確にして境相論を防止する意味があった。
sen.e: Boji was put up in order to clarify a boundary so that a boundary dispute could be prevented.

sen.e: As the authority of the Imperial Court was not backed by coercive power in the medieval times, the authority of boji was not absolute.
